title: The 𝑞-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound can be improved for all but finitely many positive integers 𝑞

sections.introduction:
We consider as an alphabet any finite set of q𝑞q symbols such as ℤq={0,1,…,q−1}subscriptℤ𝑞01…𝑞1\mathbb{Z}_{q}=\{0,1,\dotsc,q-1\}
for any positive integer q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2.
Let ℤqnsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n} denote the set of all n𝑛n-tuples
x=(x1,…,xn)𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x=(x_{1},\dotsc,x_{n}) with components in ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} for any positive integer n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1.
We define a metric on the set ℤqnsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}
by letting dH​(x,y)subscript𝑑H𝑥𝑦d_{\mathrm{H}}(x,y) be the number of positions
in which the components of the two n𝑛n-tuples x𝑥x and y𝑦y in ℤqnsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n} differ,
which is called the Hamming distance between x𝑥x and y𝑦y.
A q𝑞q-ary code with length n𝑛n is a nonempty subset 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} of ℤqnsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}
and its elements are called codewords.
Let ℕℕ\mathbb{N} and ℙℙ\mathbb{P} denote the sets of positive integers and of prime numbers,
respectively.
If the size of 𝒞𝒞{\cal C}, denoted by |𝒞|𝒞|{\cal C}|, is M∈ℕ𝑀ℕM\in\mathbb{N} with M≥2𝑀2M\geq 2
and the minimum Hamming distance between any two distinct codewords in 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} is d𝑑d,
then 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} is called a q𝑞q-ary (n,M,d)𝑛𝑀𝑑(n,M,d) code.
The rate R𝑅R of the code 𝒞⊆ℤqn𝒞superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛{\cal C}\subseteq\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n} is defined by
R=1n​logq⁡|𝒞|,𝑅1𝑛subscript𝑞𝒞R=\frac{1}{n}\log_{q}|{\cal C}|,
which is a value in   .
For an arbitrary real number δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), let αq​(n,δ​n)subscript𝛼𝑞𝑛𝛿𝑛\alpha_{q}(n,\delta n) denote the maximum size of
a q𝑞q-ary code with length n𝑛n which has the minimum Hamming distance at least δ​n𝛿𝑛\delta n.
We define the asymptotic rate function as follows The determination of the rate function Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta)
is an asymptotic sphere packing problem in the space ℤqnsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞𝑛\mathbb{Z}_{q}^{n}
with Hamming distance as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty,
which has been considered as a central problem
in combinatorial coding theory (see van Lint  and Manin ).
The asymptotic rate function Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta) plays a fundamental role
in Shannon’s information theory as well
(see  and ).
It is intimately related to the achievable probability of decoding error
in reliable transmission of information,
which approaches 00 exponentially as the number n𝑛n of channel uses goes to infinity.
The better a lower bound for the rate function Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta) exists,
the larger the error-exponent can be achieved by a sequence of error-correcting codes. In the recent works [ref]7 and ,
Conlon, Fox, et al. established and explored a tight connection
between set-coloring Ramsey numbers and error-correcting codes.
Therefore, one may expect that the main results obtained in this paper
would be useful for deriving some nontrivial asymptotic bound for set-coloring Ramsey numbers. It is known that for all integers q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2,
if 1−q−1≤δ<11superscript𝑞1𝛿11-q^{-1}\leq\delta<1, then Rq​(δ)=0subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿0R_{q}(\delta)=0.
The exact value of Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta), however, is not known
for any integer q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 and real number δ∈(0,1−q−1)𝛿01superscript𝑞1\delta\in(0,1-q^{-1}).
A famous lower bound for Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta)
is the following q𝑞q-ary asymptotic Gilbert–Varshamov bound
3,  for all integers q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 and 0<δ<1−q−10𝛿1superscript𝑞10<\delta<1-q^{-1}. Although it was obtained in the 1950s by simple combinatorial arguments in 3
or with the probabilistic method in ,
the q𝑞q-ary asymptotic Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) was thought for a long time
that it would be equal to the rate function Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta). Let 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} be a finite field with q𝑞q elements, where q𝑞q is a prime power.
A q𝑞q-ary code 𝒞⊆𝔽qn𝒞superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛{\cal C}\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} with length n𝑛n is called linear
if it is a subspace of the vector space 𝔽qnsuperscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑛\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.
In 1981, Goppa 5 found a remarkable connection
between algebraic curves over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} and q𝑞q-ary linear codes
and showed, through the Riemann–Roch theorem, that a better code can be obtained
from an algebraic curve over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} with more rational points given its genus.
In 1982, by using Goppa codes 5 from algebraic curves over finite fields,
Tsfasman, Vladut, and Zink  employed the classic modular curves and the Shimura curves,
and successfully improved the Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q)
for q𝑞q being a prime power of p2superscript𝑝2p^{2} (p≥7𝑝7p\geq 7)
and of p4superscript𝑝4p^{4} (p≥3𝑝3p\geq 3)
and δ𝛿\delta in an open subinterval of (0,1−q−1)01superscript𝑞1(0,1-q^{-1}).
This discovery was the first breakthrough after over twenty years of searching for a lower bound
to beat the Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) for certain q𝑞q and δ𝛿\delta. We are going to present briefly theory of Goppa codes from algebraic curves over finite fields.
The following work in this paper on lower bounds of the rate function
will be based on Lenstra codes from geometry of numbers, which can be viewed as
being analogous to Goppa codes. In 1982, Manin  firstly described such connection for algebraic geometers with some arising unsolved problems for drawing their attention.
In 1982, Ihara 9 defined the following number where Nq​(g)subscript𝑁𝑞𝑔N_{q}(g) is the maximum number of rational points
that a non-singular absolutely irreducible algebraic curve over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} of genus g𝑔g
can have.
Ihara’s number A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) is well-defined by the Hasse–Weil theorem,
namely, the Riemann hypothesis for algebraic curves over finite fields
.
Ihara 9 obtained that
A​(q)≥q−1𝐴𝑞𝑞1A(q)\geq\sqrt{q}-1 when q=p2​m𝑞superscript𝑝2𝑚q=p^{2m}, p𝑝p prime and m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N},
and provided an upper bound for A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) for all q𝑞q being a prime power.
It has been proved that Goppa codes imply (see Manin [26, p. 718]) for all q𝑞q being a prime power
and 0<δ<10𝛿10<\delta<1.
According to Manin [26, p. 719],
the work in Tsfasman, Vladut, and Zink ,
independently of the earlier Ihara’s work 7, 8
in the 1970s on towers of curves over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q},
showed that A​(q)≥q−1𝐴𝑞𝑞1A(q)\geq\sqrt{q}-1 when q=p2𝑞superscript𝑝2q=p^{2} or q=p4𝑞superscript𝑝4q=p^{4}, p𝑝p prime,
and hence from (3) that the Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) was improved
for q=p2𝑞superscript𝑝2q=p^{2} (p≥7𝑝7p\geq 7)
or q=p4𝑞superscript𝑝4q=p^{4} (p≥3𝑝3p\geq 3)
and δ𝛿\delta in an interval of (δ1,δ2)subscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2(\delta_{1},\delta_{2}) including q−12​q−1𝑞12𝑞1\frac{q-1}{2q-1}
(see [49, p. 28]).
It is noted that a better upper bound of A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) was also obtained,
which is called as the Drinfeld–Vladut bound ,
asserting that A​(q)≤q−1𝐴𝑞𝑞1A(q)\leq\sqrt{q}-1 for all q𝑞q being a prime power.
It had improved a previous upper bound of Ihara 9.
The Drinfeld–Vladut bound is tight when q=p2​m𝑞superscript𝑝2𝑚q=p^{2m}, p𝑝p prime and m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N},
from the aforementioned lower bound of A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) due to Ihara 9. Goppa codes from algebraic curves over finite fields are also called as algebraic geometry codes
(see the monographs  and ).
It is well-known that algebraic curves over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} can be equivalently replaced
in the language of algebraic function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} .
In the case of q𝑞q being an even power of a prime,
Garcia and Stichtenoth 2
found an alternative approach with the Artin–Schreier tower of algebraic function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}
to attain the Drinfeld–Vladut bound.
When q𝑞q is an odd power of a prime but not a prime with q>125𝑞125q>125,
Bassa, Beelen, Garcia, and Stichtenoth 
showed that the Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) can also be improved
by using appropriate infinite towers of algebraic function fields over finite fields 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}. In 1983, Serre 8, 9 demonstrated that
there exists a constant c>0𝑐0c>0 such that
A​(q)≥1c​log⁡q𝐴𝑞1𝑐𝑞A(q)\geq\frac{1}{c}\log q
for any integer q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 being a prime power,
by using class field theory for algebraic function fields over 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}
(see also the recent monograph by Serre ).
This bound is still the best known lower bound for A​(q)𝐴𝑞A(q) in general for q𝑞q being a prime.
By using (3), we have the following Serre’s lower bound for any integer q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 being a prime power and 0<δ<1−q−10𝛿1superscript𝑞10<\delta<1-q^{-1}.
It was shown in Niederreiter and Xing 2
that the constant c𝑐c in (4)
can be chosen as 96​log⁡296296\log 2 for q≥2𝑞2q\geq 2 being a prime power
or 75​log⁡275275\log 2 for q≥224𝑞superscript224q\geq 2^{24} being a prime power.
With this explicit constant c𝑐c,
it can be checked that Serre’s lower bound (4)
is not better than the Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) for any integer q𝑞q being a prime
and 0<δ<1−q−10𝛿1superscript𝑞10<\delta<1-q^{-1}. In 1985, Zinoviev and Litsyn  demonstrated that
the algebraic geometry codes can be modified by an alphabet reduction procedure
to improve the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q)
at the specific tangent point
δ=δ0=def(q−1)/(q′+q−1)∈(0,1)𝛿subscript𝛿0superscriptdef𝑞1superscript𝑞′𝑞101\delta=\delta_{0}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\mathrm{def}}}{{=}}(q-1)/(q^{\prime}+q-1)\in(0,1)
of the curve RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q) for all q≥46𝑞46q\geq 46,
where q′superscript𝑞′q^{\prime} is the cardinality of the alphabet for the applied algebraic geometry codes
(see also , [47, p. 267, Theorem 4.5.36.]).
Note that q′superscript𝑞′q^{\prime} is a prime power but not a prime in the application .
It is mentioned that a relevant and more recent work is presented by Elkies in 2001 0. We note that if q=p𝑞𝑝q=p is a generic prime,
it is not possible that
the tangent point δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0}
can cover the value δ=1/2𝛿12\delta=1/2 for almost all p𝑝p.
If δ0=1/2subscript𝛿012\delta_{0}=1/2 or is very close to 1/2121/2, then the prime p=q′+1𝑝superscript𝑞′1p=q^{\prime}+1 or is very close to q′+1superscript𝑞′1q^{\prime}+1.
Assume that p≤N𝑝𝑁p\leq N, where the positive integer N𝑁N is large.
There are at least Ω​(N/log⁡N)Ω𝑁𝑁\Omega(N/\log N) primes p𝑝p between 2 and N𝑁N,
while there are at most O​(N1/2/log⁡N)𝑂superscript𝑁12𝑁O(N^{1/2}/\log N) prime powers q′superscript𝑞′q^{\prime},
which is not a prime, between 1 and 2​N2𝑁2N.
Therefore, it cannot be true that p=q′+1𝑝superscript𝑞′1p=q^{\prime}+1 or is very close to q′+1superscript𝑞′1q^{\prime}+1
for almost all primes p𝑝p.
Hence, there are infinitely many primes p𝑝p for which
δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0} cannot cover the value δ=1/2𝛿12\delta=1/2 for q=p𝑞𝑝q=p.
Next, if q𝑞q is a generic non-prime-power positive integer, then the finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}
with q𝑞q elements does not exist.
In the same spirit, we can see that there are infinitely many such q𝑞q for which
the tangent point δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0} cannot cover the value δ=1/2𝛿12\delta=1/2. Based on the above analysis of previously obtained results in the existing literature,
it can be stated that the q𝑞q-ary Gilbert–Varshamov bound RGV​(δ,q)subscript𝑅GV𝛿𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(\delta,q)
at δ=1/2𝛿12\delta=1/2, i.e., RGV​(1/2,q)subscript𝑅GV12𝑞R_{\mathrm{GV}}(1/2,q),
remains the currently largest known lower bound of the rate function Rq​(δ)subscript𝑅𝑞𝛿R_{q}(\delta)
at δ=1/2𝛿12\delta=1/2, i.e., Rq​(1/2)subscript𝑅𝑞12R_{q}(1/2),
for infinitely many positive integers q𝑞q
which is a generic prime and which is a generic non-prime-power integer.
